questions.text: The posture seen in the image is characteristic of which poisoning?
questions.solution:
The image shows Opisthotonus posturing.It is a characteristic occurrence of strychnine poisoning.

Risus sardonicus/Lockjaw is another feature that may be seen, but is not specific for strychnine poisoning.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy accidentally ate the fruit shown in the image below. He presents with blurred vision, slurred speech, urinary retention, and confusion. On examination, the pupils are dilated, the mouth is dry, and the face appears flushed. What is the antidote of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image of a cherry-like, highly toxic fruit are suggestive of Atropa belladonna poisoning. It is a deliriant poison. The appropriate antidote of choice is physostigmine.

Atropa belladonna acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine. All the parts of the plants are toxic. The active principle is 1-hyoscyamine.

The signs and symptoms, treatment, and postmortem appearances are similar to those associated with Datura poisoning. Clinical manifestations can be remembered with 9D's: dryness of mouth, dysarthria, dysphagia, dilation of cutaneous blood vessels, diplopia, dry hot skin, drunken gait, delirium, and drowsiness. On examination, dilation of the pupils, flushing of the face, and congestion of the cornea can be seen.

Note:

Deliriant poisons are poisons that produce a well-marked deliriant or confusional stage, like Datura, Belladonna, Hyoscyamus, Cannabis, and cocaine.

Other options

Options A and B- Atropine and pralidoxime are antidotes used in organophosphorus poisoning.

Option C- Sodium amytal is used as an antidote for strychnine which is a spinal poison.

    • Delirium
    • Drowsiness
    • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

questions.text: Activated charcoal is a:
questions.solution:
Activated charcoal acts as a mechanical antidote.

Mechanical antidotes- They neutralise poisons by mechanical action or prevention of their absorption.

  • Activated charcoal- It acts mechanically by adsorbing and retaining organic and mineral poisons within its pores and thus delays the absorption from the stomach.
  • Demulcents- substances that coat the gastric mucous membrane and thus do not permit the poisons to    cause any damage, e.g. milk, starch, egg-white, mineral oil, milk of magnesia, aluminium hydroxide gel, etc
  • Bulky food is the mechanical antidote to glass powder, wherein it acts by imprisoning its particles within its meshes.

Chemical antidotes- They neutralise poison by forming harmless or insoluble compounds or by oxidation when it is brought in contact with them.

  • Common salt decomposes silver nitrate, forming the insoluble silver chloride.
  • Potassium permanganate has oxidising properties. 1:5000 solution is used in opium poisoning.

Chelating agents (metal complexing agents) are used in the treatment of heavy metal poisoning. The metal-agent complex is more water-soluble than the metal itself, resulting in higher renal excretion of the complex.

questions.text: You were asked to conduct an autopsy of a 32-year-old man who succumbed to death due to poisoning. His organs can be preserved in rectified spirit in poisoning due to any of the following agents except?
questions.solution:
The organs can be preserved in rectified spirit, except in cases of suspected poisoning by kerosene.

Rectified spirit can be used to preserve tissue and organs in most cases of suspected poisoning. In suspected poisoning with the following, preservation with rectified spirit should be avoided:

  • Alcohol
  • Kerosene
  • Chloroform, ether
  • Chloral hydrate
  • Formic acid, Formaldehyde
  • Acetic acid
  • Phenol
  • Phosphorus, and
  • Paraldehyde

Other preservatives used in toxicology postmortem include:

  • Saturated NaCl solution: Avoided in poisoning from corrosive acids, alkalis, corrosive sublimate, and aconite.
  • 10 mg/ml of sodium or potassium fluoride and potassium oxalate (anti-coagulant) to preserve blood.
  • Fluoride should be added to urine, CSF, and vitreous humor if alcohol estimation is required and if analysis for cocaine, cyanide, and CO is being done.

A preservative is not necessary if :

  • The viscera can be analyzed in 24 hours
  • If the sample can be stored in a refrigerator or icebox
  • Bone, hair, nails specimens
  • Lung for inhaled poisons

The viscera should not be preserved in formaldehyde because extraction of non-volatile poisons becomes difficult.

In cases of chronic poisoning with heavy metals such as lead, arsenic, mercury, antimony, copper, etc., the shaft of a long bone, strands of scalp hair, fingernails or toenails, and a wedge of the quadriceps muscle should also be taken for sampling.

questions.text: A 45 year old iron smelter, presents to the OPD with history of rice water diarrhoea. The image shows the clinical finding that the doctor notes during examination. Which of the following clinical features would be consistent with the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows transverse white lines (Leukonychia striata) called Aldrich Mees Lines typically seen in arsenic poisoning. Tremors are consistent with a diagnosis of arsenic poisoning which should be suspected in a patient of with Aldrich Mees lines, red velvety mucosa, and rice water stools.

Hyperpyrexia, Hyperpigmentation, and Anorexia are associated features.

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

questions.text: A 22-year-old mother of a newborn is brought to the emergency department with nausea, abdominal cramps, and massive desquamation of the skin. The patient presents with a red skin rash,  affecting mainly the soles, palms, and buttocks. Further probing reveals that she had consumed the substance shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features suggest boiled lobster syndrome seen in poisoning with boric acid, a common household poison commonly seen in baby powders, lotions, and antiseptics used in the treatment of diaper dermatitis.

Boric acid is used as an antiseptic and insecticide.

In severe poisoning with boric acid, a red skin rash, most often affecting palms, soles, and buttocks, can be seen. The characteristic appearance is known as "boiled lobster appearance," which is marked by intense erythema, followed by extensive exfoliation.

Other options:

Option A- Pink disease or acrodynia is caused due to hypersensitivity reaction resulting from repeated ingestion or contact with mercury. There are pinkish morbilliform/ acral rashes, desquamation of palms and soles, pain in the extremities, excessive salivation or perspiration, photophobia, anorexia, insomnia, constipation or diarrhea, etc.

Option B- Blackfoot disease is caused due to chronic arsenic poisoning. Chronic arsenic poisoning causes peripheral vascular insufficiency, leading to dry gangrene.

Option D- Erethism refers to psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity, which is commonly seen among persons working in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterized by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia.

Eponymous features associated with mercury poisoning:

  • Danbury tremors are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Hatter's shakes/Glass blower's shakes.
  • Acrodynia (Pink disease)
  • Minamata disease: This is caused by the eating of fish poisoned by mercury.
  • Erethism: These are psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity, which is seen among persons working in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterized by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia.
  • Mercuria lentis: This term refers to the peculiar eye change seen due to exposure to mercury vapor. It appears as brownish deposits of mercury on the anterior lens capsule.

Eponymous features associated with arsenic poisoning:

  • Raindrop pigmentation - seen on temples, eyelids, and neck
  • Aldrich-Mee’s lines - white lines on finger and toe nails
  • Hyperkeratosis of palms and soles
  • Blackfoot disease - a gangrenous condition affecting the extremities

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman came to the emergency department with severe pain in both legs, after she underwent an induced abortion using ergotamine. On examination, her legs were cold and pale, and peripheral arterial pulses were not felt. Which of the following drugs can be used as an antidote in treating the condition?
questions.solution:
Nitroprusside can be used as an antidote to reverse the ergot-induced vasospasm.

Nitroprusside is a non-selective vasodilator. It acts by releasing NO, which activates the guanylyl cyclase - cyclic GMP – protein kinase G pathway, leading to vasodilation. This mechanism mimics the production of NO by vascular endothelial cells.

Therapeutic uses:

  • It is primarily used in the treatment of hypertensive emergencies.
  • To lower blood pressure during aortic dissection. It is important to administer beta blocker with nitroprusside in aortic dissection to reduce heart rate, because if nitroprusside is given alone, it causes increased myocardial contractility, which in turn increases the rate of increase in aortic pressure and may further aggravate the dissection.
  • To improve cardiac output in patients with congestive heart failure, especially with hypertension and pulmonary edema, who are refractory to other treatments.
  • To decrease myocardial oxygen demand after myocardial infarction.
  • To induce controlled hypotension during anesthesia, and reduce bleeding during surgical procedures.
  • To reverse the vasospastic action of the ergot alkaloids, such as ergotamine and ergonovine.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old drowsy male was brought to the casualty. His pulse was 130/min, respiratory rate -30/min. His lab reports are given below. He showed improvement on nasogastric aspiration and administration of sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole. What substance did he most likely consume?

ABG - metabolic acidosis

Total serum calcium - 6.8 mg/dL

Blood Urea – 100 mg/dl

Creatinine – 3.4 mg/dl

Urine analysis - Calcium oxalate crystals.
questions.solution:
The given scenario point towards ethylene glycol poisoning.

Ethylene glycol is converted to glyoxyaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Glyoxyaldehyde causes kidney damage. 

Methanol is converted to formaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Formaldehyde causes retinal damage like blurring of vision/loss of vision.

The principles of treatment for both these conditions are the same. It predominantly involves using fomipezole or ethanol to inhibit the metabolic conversion of these relatively non-toxic alcohols to their toxic metabolites.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with suspected poisoning was brought to the casualty by his friends. On examination, the finding shown below is seen. Which of the following is the likely poisoning in this case?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a carpopedal spasm which is seen in hypocalcemia. Oxalic acid poisoning is associated with hypocalcemia.

In oxalic acid poisoning, those who survive for a few hours develop hypocalcemia, because oxalic acid readily combines with the calcium ion in the body tissues and forms calcium oxalate.

The features of oxalic acid poisoning include tenderness in the epigastrium, nausea, followed by coffee ground-colored vomitus, severe thirst, diarrhea, electrolyte imbalance, and death.

Acute features of oxalic acid poisoning are mainly due to hypocalcemia such as: 

  • Muscle irritability
  • Tenderness
  • Tetany
  • Convulsions
  • Tingling of extremities
  • Coma
  • Collapse and death

Delayed features of oxalic acid poisoning include uremia. Urine is scanty with traces of albumin, blood, and calcium oxalate crystals (seen microscopically as envelope-shaped crystals). Large doses of oxalic acid cause shock and lead to death. 

Antidotes: Lime water, calcium lactate, calcium gluconate, calcium chloride, and chalk suspension in water or milk may be given orally, and act as specific antidotes, which form insoluble calcium oxalate and are excreted easily.

Medicolegal importance: Oxalic acid is used to erase writing in attempts at forgery.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of corrosives

Corrosive Mechanism of Action Type of necrosis
Strong acids Hydrogen ions penetrate tissues and lead to cell death and eschar formation. This prevents further hydrogen ion penetration and protects against deeper injury. Coagulation necrosis
Carbolic acid Same as other strong acids, but also hardens the GI mucosa. Produces a leather bottle stomach and anesthetizes the nerve endings. This allows for gastric lavage. Coagulation necrosis 
Oxalic acid Same as other strong acids, but also scavenges calcium ions, leading to hypocalcemia and Calcium oxalate renal stones.  Coagulation necrosis
Hydrofluoric acid Fluoride ions scavenge intracellular cations, such as calcium and magnesium and inhibit Na/K ATPase, disrupting cell membranes. This leads to hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia. Liquefactive necrosis
Strong alkalis Hydroxide ions easily penetrate tissues, leading to the dissolution of cell membranes. It is associated with deep tissue injury. Liquefactive necrosis

questions.text: A worker found in a burning chemical factory is brought to the emergency in a state of hypotension and is suspected to have been exposed to hydrogen cyanide gas. Which of the following is best avoided during his management?
questions.solution:
Nitrites should be avoided in patients with cyanide toxicity presenting with hypotension, especially in the setting of concomitant carbon monoxide exposure.

Burning buildings are a source of carbon monoxide exposure and can result in carboxyhaemoglobin. Nitrites are used in cyanide poisoning because of their ability to form methemoglobin, which binds cyanide more avidly than the ferric iron of cytochrome oxidase. Nitrite therapy should be avoided for those with both cyanide and CO poisoning because these compounds work by inducing methemoglobin formation, which further reduces the oxygen content of blood in patients with carboxyhemoglobin accumulation.

Treatment of Cyanide Poisoning in Adults

  1. 100% oxygen
  2. IV crystalloids and vasopressors for hypotension
  3. Sodium bicarbonate for acidemia
  4. Either Cyanide antidote kit
    • Amyl nitrite inhaler - crack vial and inhale over 30 s.
    • 3% solution Sodium nitrite  -300 mg IV given over no less than 5 min.
    • 25% solution Sodium thiosulfate: 12.5 g IV. 
  5. Or Hydroxocobalamin - 5 g IV over 15 min, up to 10 g. 

Hydroxocobalamin(Vitamin B12a) is a metalloprotein with a cobalt center that binds cyanide, thereby removing it from cytochrome oxidase and forming cyanocobalamin. It is FDA-approved for the management of cyanide poisoning and is considered ideal in cases where the diagnosis of cyanide poisoning is uncertain or in cases where the methemoglobinemia induction would be detrimental, i.e., concomitant exposure to carbon monoxide as in building fires.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman was found unconscious in her room by her husband. Beside her, he found an empty bottle of phenobarbital which she was prescribed for seizures. He rushed her to the ER. All of the following can be done to manage this case except:

choices.text: Alkaline diuresis to excrete the drug

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests barbiturate poisoning. Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist and has no effect on barbiturate toxicity. There is no antidote for barbiturate poisoning.

Management of barbiturate poisoning:

  • Maintain airway, breathing, circulation
  • Electrolyte balance
  • Gastric lavage
  • Alkaline diuresis by giving sodium bicarbonate
  • Hemodialysis in severe cases

Benzodiazepines have largely replaced barbiturates both medically and recreationally due to their wider therapeutic window. Despite the decline in barbiturate use, cases of acute poisoning with severe toxicity are still noted at staggering rates in developing countries, where the affordability of barbiturates lend to their increased use as anticonvulsants.

questions.text:
A patient was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after he consumed a bottle of illicit liquor. His ABG shows metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition?

ABG - Arterial blood gas
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the Arterial blood gas analysis (ABG) showing metabolic acidosis is suggestive of methanol toxicity. Fomepizole is used for the treatment of this condition.

Methanol poisoning is caused due to ingestion of illicit liquor which contains ethanol adulterated with methanol. Methanol is metabolized to formaldehyde and formic acid by alcohol and aldehyde dehydrogenases, respectively. The metabolites of methanol are responsible for the toxic effects.

Clinically, patients present with headache, vomiting, abdomen pain, uneasiness, confusion, delirium, and coma. Formic acid specifically damages the retina and optic nerve and results in blurring of vision and blindness.

Elevated levels of formic acid and other organic acids result in metabolic acidosis on ABG.

Treatment of methanol poisoning includes keeping the patient in a quiet, dark room to protect the eyes from the light. Gastric lavage with sodium bicarbonate if the patient is brought within 2 hours of ingesting methanol to combat acidosis. Ethanol infusion since ethanol is preferentially metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase over methanol and helps by reducing the rate of generation of formaldehyde and formic acid.

Fomepizole is a specific inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase and the drug of choice for methanol poisoning. Folate therapy with calcium leucovorin reduces blood formate levels by enhancing its oxidation. Hemodialysis is used in severe cases of methanol toxicity.

Other options: 

Option B: Flumazenil is the inverse agonist of benzodiazepine receptors and is used for the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose.

Option C: N-acetyl cysteine is used as an antidote for the treatment of paracetamol poisoning.

Option D: Naloxone is a competitive opioid antagonist used for the treatment of opioid overdose.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy?
questions.solution:
ε-Aminocaproic acid can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy.

It is a lysine analog that binds competitively to plasminogen, blocking plasminogen from binding to fibrin and the subsequent conversion to plasmin. This activity subsequently results in the inhibition of fibrinolysis.

It should not be given unless hemorrhage is life-threatening because it inhibits intrinsic fibrinolytic activity and can precipitate DIC. Fresh frozen plasma and cryoprecipitate may also be used to replenish fibrin and clotting factors.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient on anticoagulant therapy for his DVT started coughing up blood. He has a history of irregular warfarin intake. Workup revealed elevated INR and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. Which of the following agents would be the best choice for immediate reversal of bleeding?
questions.solution:
Immediate or urgent reversal of warfarin-induced bleeding is best achieved by the administration of prothrombin complex concentrates (PCC).

These are highly purified concentrates prepared from pooled plasma and contain factors II, IX, and X. Factor VII may be included or produced separately.

Option D: Vitamin K1 is the specific antidote for warfarin-induced bleeding, but it takes 6-24 hours for the clotting factors to be resynthesized and released in blood after Vitamin K administration and hence its action is delayed for several hours.  

Option A: Cryoprecipitate mainly contains factor VIII and fibrinogen and therefore is not suitable for warfarin-induced bleeding, as warfarin inhibits factors II, VII, IX, X.

Option B: Fresh frozen plasma can also be used but prothrombin complex concentrate normalizes the INR more rapidly.

questions.text: Acrodynia is seen in poisoning with which of the following metals?
questions.solution:
Acrodynia, or pink disease, is seen in chronic mercury poisoning.

Acrodynia is the dermatological manifestation of mercury poisoning. Children are usually affected by this hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by sweating and skin rash, with hands and feet becoming puffy, pinkish, and painful. Associated paresthesia and skin peeling are also seen.

Features of chronic mercury poisoning include:

  • Hydrargyrism - These patients have Danbury tremors, which are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Hatter's shakes/ Glass blower's shakes
  • Acrodynia (pink disease)
  • Minimata disease - caused by the eating of fish poisoned by mercury
  • Erethism - these are psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity seen in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterised by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia
  • Mercuria lentis - peculiar eye changes due to exposure to mercury vapor.

questions.text:
Identify the medical presentations associated with the deliriant poison derived from the plant given below.
  1. Magnan syndrome
  2. Amotivational syndrome
  3. Run amok
  4. Nasal septum ulceration
  5. Loss of self-respect
questions.solution:
The given plant is Erythroxylum coca. Cocaine is the principal alkaloid found in the cultivated varieties of coca. The correct answer is 1, 4, and 5 only.

Cocaine is a CNS stimulant. CNS stimulation (anxiety, hyperactivity), CVS overactivity (tachycardia, hypertension), and increased respiratory rate are seen in poisoning with cocaine causing sympathetic toxidrome.

The water-soluble form (-hydrochloride) can be injected or snorted. Tattoos may be made to cover the injection marks. Whilst another form (-sulfate) can be smoked. It gives a cracking sound when burnt. It inhibits the uptake of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin. It thus, enhances the action of these neurotransmitters.

It causes digestive disturbances, anorexia, salivation, tachycardia, tachypnoea, and insomnia. The face is pale, eyes sunken, pupils dilated, and the gaze is shifty. 
 
Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs is a characteristic feature in which there is a feeling as if grains of sand are under the skin or as if small insects are creeping on the skin, giving rise to an itching sensation (formication, tactile hallucination) and resultant excoriation, which leads to irregular scratches and ulcers.
 
It is a drug of addiction and causes a lowering of moral tone and loss of decency and self-respect. Sniffing habits leads to nasal septum ulceration.

Initial management involves the administration of activated charcoal and gastric lavage if it has been ingested.

Treatment involves the administration of benzodiazepines to control heart rate/ seizures, propranolol to control cardiac arrhythmia, and haloperidol to treat psychosis. Counseling needs to be done to avoid resisting the urge for repetitive usage. 

Other options: Run amok and amotivational syndrome are associated with chronic poisoning with Cannabis sativa.

  • Amotivational syndrome - Chronic use of Cannabis may lead to amotivational syndrome with lethargy, and lack of interest in day-to-day activities.
  • Run-amok - Run-amok is a psychic disturbance resulting from the continued use or sudden consumption of Cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania. The person is not held responsible for his acts since ‘run amok’ is considered a disorder of mind and not intoxication.

questions.text: A young man was brought dead following deliberate consumption of the given plant. All of the aspects of this plant are true, except ______.

choices.text: Smoke from burning plant carries the toxic material
Can be detected even from the burnt dead body

questions.solution:
The given plant is Nerium odorum, all parts of the plant are poisonous, except the roots.

Oleanders: They are of two varieties - 

  • Nerium odorum or white oleander -
    • Bears with white or pink flowers
    • All parts of the plant are poisonous except the roots
    • They contain cardiac glycosides - primarily oleandroside (oleandrin) and nerioside (nerin)
    • The nectar of the flower yields poisonous honey
  • Cerbera thevetia or yellow oleander -
    • All parts of the plant are poisonous
    • All active principles are glycosides

The manifestations of Nerium odorum poisoning includes contact dermatitis, headache, dizziness, respiratory difficulty and nausea. Ingestion may lead to vomiting, abdominal pain, frothy salivation and diarrhea. Initially, there is bradycardia followed by tachycardia and again weak pulses. Other changes include hypotension, fibrillation, AV block, mydriasis, tetanic spasms, lock-jaw, drowsiness, and coma. Death is usually from cardiac failure. 

The manifestation of Cerbera thevetia poisoning include burning sensation in the mouth, tingling of the tongue, dryness of the throat, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, dilated pupils, irregular action of the heart followed by drowsiness, coma, collapse, and death.

Postmortem appearances: Organs appear congested. The Nerium resists heat, therefore can be detected even from the burnt dead body.

Medicolegal aspects: Suicide with this is common among villagers, accidental poisoning can also be seen, but homicide is rare. It is also used as cattle poison. Smoke from burning plants carries toxic material.

questions.text: A person has been bitten by the following snake. Which of the following options describe the symptoms seen classically in this snake bite?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows common krait, which is neurotoxic and shows classical symptoms such as muscle paralysis.

The neurotoxicity symptoms that would be seen in the patient include: 

  • headache
  • blurred vision
  • perioral paraesthesia
  • hyperacusis
  • dizziness
  • vertigo
  • gooseflesh
  • vomiting
  • hypersalivation

Neurotoxicity effects are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase or they may wear off spontaneously in about a week.

Other options:

Option A: Anaphylaxis is seen in poisoning due to stiletto snakes. Other symptoms include pain, swelling, blisters and local lymph node enlargements.

Option B: Systemic bleeding such as intravascular hemolysis, ecchymosis and incoagulable blood is seen in bites due to back fanged snakes.

Option C: Myoglobinuria is seen in poisoning due to sea snakes.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency room with profound drowsiness. On examination, he is found to have respiratory depression, with a respiratory rate of 5 cycles/minute. His symptoms are traced back to a drug derived from the plant shown below. Which of the following is the antidote to this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The suitable antidote to this patient presenting with features of opiate intoxication is naloxone. The derivative drug, opium is derived from the Papaver somniferum plant as shown in the clinical vignette.

Toxic parts of the plant include the unripe fruit capsule and the latex juice. Active principles of opium are grouped under phenanthrenes (morphine, codeine, heroin) and benzyl-isoquinolones (papaverine, narcotin).

These drugs act on mu, kappa, delta receptors in the CNS and mediate the effects of euphoria, analgesia, respiratory depression, gastrointestinal dysmotility, and miosis. 

The antidote to opiate intoxication is a competitive opiate antagonist named naloxone which competes with opioids at their receptor sites. Dose: 0.4-2 mg IV (It may be repeated every 10-15 minutes up to a maximum dose of 10 mg).

Other options:

Option A - Flumazenil is the antidote to treat benzodiazepine (BZD) intoxication. Benzodiazepines (alprazolam, flunitrazepam) are sedative-hypnotics and symptoms of intoxication include normal vital signs, sedation, diplopia, ataxia, slurred speech, and impaired motor function. Flumazenil acts as a competitive antagonist at the site of BZD action, which is the gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor. 

Option C - Physostigmine is used in the treatment of anticholinergic toxicity due to atropine. Atropine is the anticholinergic active principle derived from tropane alkaloids such as Datura stramonium and Atropa belladonna. Toxidrome consists of features such as tachycardia, hyperthermia, agitation, delirium, mydriasis, dry flushed skin, and urinary retention. Physostigmine is a reversible acetylcholine esterase inhibitor that increases acetylcholine concentrations in the synaptic cleft to mitigate the effects of atropine toxicity. 

Option D - Atropine is used in the treatment of cholinergic toxicity due to organophosphates (DDT, parathion, malathion). Symptoms of cholinergic toxicity include bradycardia, respiratory depression, and autonomic symptoms of salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation. Atropine used in association with pralidoxime act as competitive inhibitors at the nicotinic and muscarinic acetylcholine receptors to neutralize the toxicity.

questions.text: A patient on anticoagulant therapy presented to the casualty with an uncontrolled bleeding episode and was given IV protamine sulfate. However, the patient did not respond to the treatment. Which of the following anticoagulant agents was most likely being used by the patient?
questions.solution:
Since no effect was noted with protamine sulfate, the likely anticoagulant in use must be fondaparinux. This is because protamine sulfate fails to bind the drug. 

Protamine sulfate binds tightly to heparin and neutralizes its anticoagulant effect. It partially reverses the anticoagulant activity of LMWH also. But it has no effect on fondaparinux.

There is no known specific antidote approved for use in fondaparinux overdose. Fondaparinux-associated bleeding complications are managed by treatment discontinuation and search for the primary cause. Surgical hemostasis, blood replacements, fresh plasma transfusion, plasmapheresis should be considered.
